creator: Mackay, John Alexander, 1838-1923. (compiler and translator)
description: Mackay, John Alexander: 1838-1923. Native of Moosonee, Ontario; trained under Bishop Horden; ordained in the Church of England, 1862; at York Factory, 1862-1864, Stanley, 1864-1876, Nepowewin and Carlton, 1876-1877, and Battleford, 1877-1879; Cree tutor at Emmanuel College, Prince Albert, 1880-1884; in charge of Indian reserves at Battleford, 1885-1887; professor of divinity at Emmanuel, 1887-1900; superintendent of missions in diocese of Saskatchewan, 1900-1921; reorganized day school at Little Pine reserve, 1922; translator of religious works into Cree (Hopkins, Canadian annual review, 1923). // Title in Cree and English; text in Cree syllabics. Rev. H. Cochrane (in an annual letter to the Church Missionary Society in 1875): "I have not heard anything of the hymns my wife and I translated last winter 116 in a collection. I hope the Society will kindly have these printed; the people [of Devon, The Pas] are very fond of them. The Rev. Mr. McKay will print them in syllabic this winter, but we want them in the Roman character as well" (Church Missionary Society, Records and Correspondence, microfilm reel 7). At this time Mackay was at Stanley Mission where he had a press. Also published, Psalms and hymns in the language of the Cree Indians of the diocese of Saskatchewan, North-West America , London: Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, 1891, 1898, 1903, and 1911 ([2], 1 leaf, 111, [1]p.). Also published in syllabics and Roman in parallel columns, Psalms and hymns in the language of the Cree Indians of the diocese of Saskatchewan, North-West America , London: Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, 1911, 1913, 1917, [1932], and 1935 ([4], 159p.); Toronto: General Board of Religious Education, Church of England in Canada, [1927] and [1949] (159p.). Verso of title-page for [1949] printing says 13,000 copies were printed 1891-1932; 1,500 copies in 1935; 5,000 copies in 1949.

title: Psalms and hymns in the language of the Cree Indians of North-West America: Sanctioned by the bishop of Saskatchewan
